text: CO2 doesn't change climate, CO2 levels were far higher in our ancient past. Plants turn CO2 into O2. We are now at 480ppm, we have had a shortage of CO2 for 3 million years. CO2 during the durasic period CO2 was double what it is today. More CO2 = more O2 and all life thrives. Climate changes by 2 repeatable cycles, change in the earth's tilt and solar cycles.

CCS has failed miserably. there is only one CCS coal fired power station in the USA which was built as an experiment and it runs at 6 times the cost of renewable energy. CCS is a scam set up to help save the fossil fuel industry. These billions of dollars of tax payers money can simply be funneled into renewables and electric cars then there would now be a massive new industry making fossil fuels largely (partly) redundant and employing millions of people in new clean tech. text: To all the people saying plant trees instead: trees are not a viable method of carbon capture. Not only is the amount of land needed to plant enough trees prohibitively large, but trees don't actually "capture" carbon in a way that would be useful in stopping climate change. The carbon causing the problems was stored in the ground for millions of years. The only way to reverse climate change is to return the carbon to the ground and remove it from the "carbon cycle". Trees are part of the carbon cycle and all their stored carbon will be returned to the atmosphere eventually. I'm all for planting trees though, just not as a solution to climate change. Cheers!

text:
If EOR sequesters more carbon from the air than is in the oil that it pumps out, then it is carbon-negative. That's admittedly an 'if'. Unlike direct carbon sequestration, it has a business plan, and thus is economically sustainable. It is a temporary measure; it will last only as long as there is oil; but if it's carbon-negative, or at worst carbon neutral, then it will work during that time. 

EOR is economically sustainable, but not resource sustainable. Direct sequestration is resource sustainable, if renewably powered, but not economically sustainable. Conversion to feedstock is sustainable both ways, but is only carbon-neutral.

text:
@Robert Tackett  The general efficency of sunlight to useful energy in plants is generously considered about 1%, wereas solar panels are pushing towards 20% or more. Plants' ability to store carbon long-term is practically non-existent unless they get compressed into the earth/beneath the ocean and turned into coal/oil over litteral millenia. We don't have that kind of time.

With plants you need more and more area to store more and more carbon from the cycle, and their efficency at that task is crap both energy-wise, area-wise, and time-wise.

We'd need to set aside a massive amount of area to the task, and dedicate massive amounts of manpower to accomplish it, and even then it will take years - if not decades - to truly get going.

Compared with that, a carbon capture plant is more efficent, more effective, cheaper, easier, and takes up less space.

In other words, yeah. Bill Gates does indeed know more than god at capturing carbon from the atmosphere. As do I for that matter. Nature never evolved with the efficency of carbon capture and storage in mind. That has never been a task life has truly concerned itself with before now, and as such even the most rudementary of human techniques easily beats out nature's best alternatives.

text:
Technically you can. Heat magnesium in carbon dioxide. This gives you magnesium monoxide and pure carbon. Then treat the magnesium monoxide with hydrochloric acid. This gives magnesium chloride and hydrogen. The hydrogen can be stored for later. Melt down the magnesium chloride and do electrolysis. This gives you back the pure magnesium and chlorine. React the chlorine with the hydrogen and you got your hydrochloric acid back. No waste products, pure carbon output.

The problem is that you wouldn’t want to do this if you want to profit in any way because the costs outweigh anything you can make selling the carbon.

text:
I don't entirely agree. We could potentially get to a place where the carbon emissions we produce are equalised by carbon capture and other technologies. Along side this, we can still have robust environmental regulations to avoid destroying vulnerable habitats and ecosystems. Will we ever have zero impact on the environment? I doubt that - look at the processes to mine minerals which go into creating wind turbines and solar panels. Surely a small impact compared to fossil fuels, but an impact all the same. The same goes for our incredible production of waste year on year - that's not a problem which is easily resolved. 

Personally, I have reasons to be optimistic. Governments (including states within countries, and local governments) and even corporations around the world are jumping on the green bandwagon and committing to net zero carbon targets, so I believe that we can use carbon capture as one piece in the puzzle of a cleaner, greener future for all of us. 

Corporations are not blind to the PR nightmare of environmental catastrophe and degradation, and today more than ever are conscious of what lax environmental standards do to their brand - why else would they engage in more expensive, greener approaches to their business models if all they were thinking about was profit? Take companies who buy carbon credits for example - there is no business reason to buy them, and no business reason to be environmentally friendly. Now granted, part of that is to avoid government sanctions, which must surely be a big part of their motivations.

I would have a look at some of the data on per capita CO2 production, which in the Western world is leveling off or declining, and in China has leveled off over the past decade, for example, all while per capita economic growth has boomed. What this shows is that economic growth (on a per capita basis) has been decoupled from CO2 emissions, i.e. it seems like we don't need to increase our CO2 emissions and accept all the environmental drawbacks that come along with that to generate economic growth.

Now if this is the case, and governments are aware of it, then why aren't they starting to turn the corner and loosen up environmental standards and emissions targets? Are you predicting that once the problem of carbon neutrality is solved, then they will start polluting more? If we reach a stage where economies are profitable under a net-zero scenario, then why would they care to start polluting again, especially if there is no political will to do so? If the concern is encroachment on natural habitats, perhaps consider the fact that over the past number of decades, marine and terrestrial protected areas have been increasing in size, not decreasing. Given what I mentioned above (and with what you know), do you see any reason for this to reverse?

text:
All of these technologies require energy to operate. We get most of our energy from non-renewables. You want to burn fossil fuels, to create energy, to run machines that capture a fraction of a percent of the carbon used to run the process?
The problem is that CO2 exists at a concentration 400 parts per MILLION in air, so you have to process tons of air, to get the 0.04% of CO2 out of it. And since CO2's value is very low as a commodity, there's no possible business model for commercial atmospheric carbon extraction. We would need to implement carbon taxes on producers to pay for the costs of extraction.

In order to remove all this "low water pollution" all we need to do is find a method of putting "low water"  back on top where it came from by using less energy than was capturing in it falling.

Of course this is exactly the same issue of capturing energy from "high water" carbon resulting in "low water" CO2 "pollution" and then using less energy than was initially captured in the process  by putting "high water" carbon back from its  "low water" CO2.

text: How stupid and ignorant are people who are saying "if only there was a natural way of removing CO2"? Those ways are way too slow, we need this carbon capturing tech ASAP. Yes, we should do everything we can to plant as many trees as possible and cut down as few as possible, but that alone won't do any difference anymore. So don't be an ignorant idiot, carbon capture tech is a big thing, something we now desperately need and a hell of a lot more money needs to be invested in it. Get the costs down, capture as much carbon as possible, put it underground, use it as fuel to produce energy with modern tech that only releases CO2 that can be captured again, send it off to Mars (which would actually be great for terraformation later), etc. Even if we just stuck to using it to produce synthetic fuel for cars, it's better than producing batteries for electric cars. But we can do so much more than that and that's why it's the most important thing now.

text:
You all do know that not a single climate change theory, hypothesis, and prediction has been right? Not a SINGLE one. You people think we're God and can control the entire Earth and Nature. I'm an engineer who works on renewable energy and even I think most of those green heads are stupid. "Nuclear bad, but solar good." When nuclear is more efficient and cleaner than solar, and solar only gives less than 10% return efficiency. Then you have John Kerry who takes private jets everywhere and Al Gore whose mansion puts out more CO2 in 1 month than the average American household does in a year.

In a Duke University study, from the past 35 years, 95% of CO2 has come from the ocean. 4-5% is from nature (animals, volcanoes, etc.) And less than 1% is human (with 90% of that coming from cows/farms).

In a Green Peace and University study, carbon readings show that the Earth is actually in a CO2 deficit ranking lowest in the past millions of years.

Also, it seems that the only solution to climate chage is more government control. I've seen private business say they'll implement cleaner initiatives, only for the local or federal governments to say "no, we don't trust you. We have to do it for you."

Too many of you all are being brainwashed! Have some common sense and think for yourself. Yes, cleaner more efficient energy is better. Yes we shouldn't pollute. But it is absurd to believe all these lying politicians and "scientists" (quotes because they've been caught cheating experiments, being bought off, and showing little to no scientific integrity) on everything. If it was up to them and their beliefs, we'd either be under water (Al Gore's prediction for 2010) or we would lose our entire facility system as they try to have us run everything off of solar panels and wind... imagine Alaska or Sweden when the nights are days long, etc. (And before you say they can "store the energy", no you can't. Storing energy is and has always been an issue. And if you know anything about engineering and science, you wouldn't be arguing that)

Thanks for listening to my TED TALK. (P.S. I can spout more facts and reason, but the ignorant tend to stay ignorant, so there's no use)

text: This could be fun !!   How do these people intend to neutralise Henry's Law, under which the oceans will replace the carbon-dioxide extracted from the atmosphere?  { Henry's Law says that, for a given temperature, there is a balance between the gas absorbed in the liquid and the atmosphere in contact with that liquid. If one is reduced, the other will cause a gas transfer to return to equilibrium.}  Perhaps that is why, after the months of global lockdown, the World Meteorological Organisation  reported [ November 2020 ] that there was no discernible change in the trajectory of carbon-dioxide increase.

text:
TREES DON'T REMOVE CO2 

I'm not sure who started this "viral" trend, but regarding the total amount of co2 in the atmosphere planting trees does exactly nothing. It temporarily changes the location of co2 from air to its mass, but when it inevitably dies, it will return this co2 back to the atmosphere via rotting, burning, etc...

The main issue with co2 is that we extracted "it" from the depths of the earth where it would have rested indefinitely and pumped it into our atmosphere via burning. Amount burnt or transferred from depths to the atmosphere has little effect on that 1,5 C. Our main "enemy" in that regard is the sun which heats our planet at a rate of 1kW per meter square and subsequently the fact that the heat has no way of venting out because of the glasshouse effect.

The real solution lies in developing fuel that by burning leaves more net atmosphere cooling parts than heating parts. That way, the effect can be delivered by the same vehicles that caused our problems - distributing our effort globally rather than localizing our co2 fighting efforts in the few locations where these plants have been built - which ultimately don't even turn out to be carbon negative, but carbon neutral. That makes zero sense.

text:
​ @Le Quyen  
"i am talking to a person that thinks everything is a deadend."
Ridiculous unsubstantiated claim. Simply because I'm doubtful of one unpopular idea does not make me pessimistic about every approach.


"Bamboo is a highly sort product.  From hardwood, to clothing,  and furniture products. "
That's cool, but all it proves is that bamboo is a useful resource. Do you know what else is? Wood from trees. But what does that have anything to do with carbon capture? Nothing. Even if you reuse the materials from bamboo, its co2 still escapes into the atmosphere once the plant dies.

"Nothing goes to waste."
Except the co2 that enters the atmosphere. The discussion here is about how to capture carbon dioxide, not what's the most practical resource for products.

It truly amazes me how far you can divert the conversation away from carbon capture. None of your replies have refuted my criticism about the bamboo's inefficiency.  I'm talking to a person that thinks his bamboo approach is superior to ideas that physicists, chemists, and other experts have came up with.

text: I get frustrated how oil companies have become vilified by the media. The goal should be to generate the lowest carbon energy, while improving the lives of all humans worldwide. Obviously oil and gas companies are involved with the sequestration aspect of this tech because they’re the ones with the subsurface knowledge to properly store CO2. It’s not as easy as just pumping it in the ground forever. Furthermore, no one discusses the emissions and environmental issues associated with green energy materials, but that’s a story for another day... Lastly, to the Stanford professor’s point, CO2 doesn’t store at a 1 to 1 ratio to hydrocarbon produced. Rather, due to a process called adsorption, reservoirs are able to store more CO2. In fact in some coal seams, the ratio can be as high as 10:1 (CO2 stored to methane produced). All in all this is a good video and it’s important to draw attention to this up and coming tech, however, I can definitely sense a tone of bias towards oil companies producing lower emission hydrocarbons which could be used to improve the lives of people without adequate access to energy and displace higher emission energy (coal) in places like China.
author: Jeremy Wolf

text:
Time stamp 12:46. Gee... I wonder why? If I were the reporter, I would've really asked why that was.  Well, here it is:

Theres a Canadian Study that was done recently that shows that our current CO2 levels are actually quite low.  They found that CO2 levels anywhere from 800ppm to 1500ppm GREATLY benefited nearly all plant life (few different exceptions, but the list is tiny compared to the thousands that did benefit it) compared to the 400-450ppm that our current atmosphere has today.  And CO2 levels lower than 300ppm will not sustain most fruit/vegetable bearing plants.  Im not saying we need to pump up the CO2 levels; Im saying that nearly all the fruits and veg that you get from your local grocery store benefited from being in green houses that pumped CO2 in at 3-4 times more than what we breath today.  Nearly EVERY California green house uses this system, yet youll NEVER hear about it.

text: Direct Carbon Capture does not make much sense at all. CO2 exists in the atmosphere at far less than .1%. The energy to power the fans is 99.9%+ wasted since it is mostly pulling in Nitrogen and Oxygen. Furthermore, I assume they are using an amine based separation process, which is thermodynamically expensive to perform. CO2 should be captured from fossil fuel plants. Flue gas typically contains 15% CO2, meaning far less energy is wasted to capture the same carbon. It simply seems to be a waste of resources.

text:
Thank you for producing this video, as it is a crucial technology, which requires attention and vigorous activity to advance it. Additionally, the technology is hard to track very well, given the lack of widespread focus on it. 

Like others, I am disappointed that it has not advanced further and that there is such limited policy support for direct air capture technology. The timeline on this is also not encouraging. We do not have a decade or more for this to gain widespread implementation. 

As was noted in the video by various figures, policy efforts need to be more aggressive. Evidently, Biden's agenda includes direct policy here, but we need this legislation now and we need much more of it. 

To that end, I would very much appreciate a video on related policy efforts, which might give direction on how to advance and also elevate the profile of such a policy need. The final section was informative, albeit inadequate. There's interest here, please satisfy and support it further.

text: Planting that many trees is far more complicated than many realize from an ecological perspective. If you use a single species, you are creating a monoculture that can be easily wiped out with a virus or bacteria. Also the effects from a monoculture on the local environment could potentially be devastating if done incorrectly. On the other hand, planting a diversified set of trees requires a lot of environmental research and planning. I’m not saying that we shouldn’t plant trees, I’m just saying its not as easy as the many think.

text: When I was young we studied cycles and natural recycling.  The water cycle and the carbon cycle.  Plants grew, they rotted.  They released the locked up carbon ready to recycle the carbon again.  There was a global catastrophe 350 million years ago when plants grew but did not rot down.  It simply accumulated as coal and oil and gas.  Leading to a destructive loss of CO2.  Now in nature sooner or later organisms evolve to use any energy source.  Humans have evolved to rectify the environmental disaster.  Get the carbon back into the atmosphere where it belongs.  Once done our role is complete and humans would die out.  Trying to destroy the cycle is trying to undermine the natural environment.  Which is what keeps getting us into trouble over and over again.

text:
1 gallon of regular gas costs $2.73

Burning 1 gallon gasoline produces 8.69 kg CO2

If direct carbon capture cost the anticipated $150 per net ton CO2 today, it would cost $1.30 to recapture the CO2 from the one gallon of gas

(Possibly net recapture required could be dropped by 15% if the ethanol element was from carbon neutral sources)

text:
Brazil has been experiencing with carbon neutral fuel since the early 1980s when we went bankrupt and had no more hard currency to import fuel. It's called Proálcool and Ethanol is produced from sugar cane. My car is a VW UP! 3 clininder, 1 liter, turbo engine that has a smaller carbon footprint than any Tesla. Now, we did not do that to save the planet - we did that to save our necks. In the end, it works. Brazil's gasoline has 20% ethanol as an anti-detonant and most cars are flexible and able to run with any mixture of Gasoline and Ethanol. 

We're in a situation (by "we" I mean humans) that all ideas should be tried out. I don't like, however, Oil companies using these new technologies to fake caring about the future. I also don't like people thinking only in one aspect of their idea and forgetting other impacts - that's what brought us here. One thing I really like is trees - plant a lot of trees, plant them alongside the roads, build a lot of things using wood. Carbon can be stored in really beautiful wood!

author: Timothy Mckee

text: @Timothy Mckee  You are wrong about several things: CO2 isn't 4% of the atmosphere. It's 0.04% -- 100 times less. All greenhouse gases are trace gases. That makes sense because 99% of our atmosphere is Oxygen and Nitrogen. Oxygen and Nitrogen molecules do not trap heat because of their shape. If they did our planet would be like Venus. But CO2 and the other greenhouse gases are enough to keep our planet at a moderate temperature. Consider that the Earth and Moon are both the same distance from the sun. The only reason the Earth has a warmer climate is the very small amount of CO2 and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. It's the very fact that Earth's CO2 is only 0.04% that makes this such a big deal. If CO2 were abundant our emissions wouldn't be significant enough to impact it. Before the industrial revolution, CO2 was 0.028% of the atmosphere. One-third of the CO2 in our atmosphere today is CO2 that humans emitted. CO2 traps heat, and that has been known for well over a century.
author: Adam Bram

text: @Adam Bram  On Earth having more CO2 leads to more O2. Look up Mega flora and fauna. In the past CO2 levels were much much higher long before any industry.
author: Timothy Mckee

text: @Timothy Mckee  Nobody is arguing that CO2 levels weren't higher in the ancient past. Throughout its history, Earth has gone from a molten planet to a giant snowball. There have been periods where the Earth was so warm that alligators swam in the Artic. This is all well known. The reason this is scary now is the rate of CO2 change is much, much faster than any other time in the past. Life can adapt to large swings over a long period of time. The problem is that this is happening too quickly for a lot of habitats to evolve. Millions of species will go extinct and food webs will collapse if this continues. So yes, the climate always changed. Yes, CO2 and temperatures have been much higher than today. But if you're looking at that and assuming there is nothing to worry about you've missed the point.

text: @Adam Bram  CO2 is a naturally occurring gas that is the most important nutrient on earth by orders of magnitude. Basic building block of ALL life is Carbon. Somehow the elitists have convinced you they are bad? How did we have an ice age in the Ordovician period with CO2 at 4,000ppm.... 10x today?
author: ColoradoHiker7002

text: @ColoradoHiker7002  Yes, CO2 is naturally occurring, but one-third of the CO2 in our atmosphere wouldn't be there if we didn't emit it. If life absorbed it at the rate we emit it, the concentration in the atmosphere would be static. The very fact that CO2 is 50% more than it was before the industrial revolution is proof that trees, other living things, and other carbon sinks are not absorbing it fast enough.  The Ordovician ice-age wasn't the only such event, but it goes to show a common fallacy that climate skeptics make with arguments. That's the "single-cause" fallacy. Greenhouse gases are is one of three basic things that regulate the planet's temperature. The other two are the sun and aerosols. You can have levels of CO2 and still get an ice age if the planet is getting less solar radiation or has more aerosols in the atmosphere. Similarly, I can regulate the temperature in my house by turning the heat up or opening a window. I can turn the heat all the way up, but if the windows are open it won't warm up. You have to consider multiple factors. We know CO2 is one factor. Currently, the Earth is warming even as solar irradiance is decreasing. That's a tell-tail sign that humans are causing the problem.
author: Adam Bram

text: @Adam Bram  There aren't just 3 basic things. There are the 3 earth angles, the oceans, albido, and other things. The earth has trended sideways for the last 20 years. The last 5 slightly down per NOAAs web site data. What specifically do you think is a problem?
author: ColoradoHiker7002

text: @ColoradoHiker7002  Those things you mentioned all fall into three categories: 1) Solar irradiance, 2) Greenhouse gases, and 3) Reflectivity. You are correct in mentioning albedo. Albedo and aerosols fall in the "Reflectivity" category. The point is that these three categories (or things) work together to maintain temperature. Within each category are multiple things. For example, greenhouse gases include CO2, but they also include water vapor, methane, ozone, etc. Solar irradiance takes into account the energy from the sun, the Earth's orbit, the tilt of the Earth at a given time, etc. Breaking into three broad categories makes it easier to digest. You mentioned the oceans. That would be part of the greenhouse gas category because oceans can be a carbon sink or carbon source depending on other factors. But the ultimate thing that matters is how much greenhouse gas is in the atmosphere. You said, "The earth has trended sideways for the last 20 years. The last 5 slightly down per NOAAs web site data." What is it you are referring to? The temperature, CO2 concentration, or something else? I didn't follow your question.

author: Bargdaffy 158

text:
So many answers defending this technology act as this is an isolated issue. Will carbon capture restore natural habitats? Does it help fauna and flora? 

Restoring ecosystems is a vastly better option than carbon capture which is just a way to give oil a few more decades of existence. The destruction of the amazon will affect the entire world. There's no carbon capture technology helping with that! We're in the middle of the 6th mass extinction (caused by us, humans!) and restoring ecosystems of all sorts is the way forward - not expensive palliatives for industries that have been destroying the planet for decades. The destruction of forests affects everything from water sources, to fauna and flora to the filtration of polluting gases unlike one technology dedicated to CO2 (as if that is the only problem). This is not just about CO2, it's also other gases and dying ecosystems for which this technology will divert attention from because it's trying to extend the existence of heavy polluting industries.

The problem is that there's really no economical incentive outside of carbon trading, which will become less relevant as industries will move towards more carbon neutral processes.

author: Teddy Batkin

text:
Sadly regrowing forests can only recapture the same amount of carbon that was released when those forest were cut down in the first place. It can never deal with the enormous amount of fossil carbon we've also released.
Some sort of direct air capture will probably be needed if we are going to restore the atmosphere to preindustrial CO2 levels. But I believe these current direct air capture projects are a waste of money, since the real limiting factor is the outrageous amount of non fossil energy needed for the carbon capture process. I don't see a point in playing with direct air capture until every coal plant in the world is shut down and the last gas fired plants are being phased out. Until then, this is mostly just for show.

author: Xyz Same

text: @Xyz Same  during the measured time period of millions of years going back the amount of CO2 in atmosphere varies between 200 and 5000 parts per million (or billion, its not critical here). Currently we are at 400 parts. This is to address your nonsense about "one of the usual talking points) Also 80% of the time Earth experienced an ice age, and we now are living through a warm period. Also, human activity only adds 4% to the annual overall CO2 emission on the planet. So if we currently are living during the warm period, AND we have a historically very low reading of CO2 in the atmosphere, would it not be reasonable to conclude that OTHER things dictate the climate, such as solar cycles and Earth's orbit oscillations? And if there were periods of earths history with 5000 units vs current 400 units of CO2 in the atmosphere AND Earth is not currently Venus, then isnt it blatantly obvious that we have a LOOOOOOONG way to go by adding one twenty-fifth of total CO2 emissions in the atmosphere? During the 1990s they promised all major port cities in the world to be under water if we didnt stop producing CO2 as we did back then, however, since then people are making almost twice the amount of CO2 and none of the coastal cities are as much as half-flooded. The conclusion: you really have to be an ignorant fool to believe the "expert's" story.
